{{Infobox musical artist |background =non_vocal_instrumentalist |instrument =[[Guitar]] | name = Delaney Bramlett | image = Delaney & Bonnie.png | caption = Delaney and [[Bonnie Bramlett]] in 1971 | birth_date = {{birth date|1939|7|1}}
[[Pontotoc, Mississippi]], [[United States]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2008|12|27|1939|7|1}}
[[Los Angeles]], [[California]], United States | genre = [[Blues]]
[[Rock music|Rock]]
[[Country music|Country]]
[[Gospel Music|Gospel]] | label = Magnolia Gold, Elektra, Atco, Atlantic, Crescendo, Motown, MGM, Columbia, Stax, CBS Various (see 'Discography')}} '''Delaine Alvin "Delaney" Bramlett''' (July 1, 1939 – December 27, 2008) was an [[United States|American]] singer, [[songwriter]], musician, and [[record producer|producer]]. Bramlett's five-decade career reached peaks in creativity, performance, and notoriety in partnership with his then-wife [[Bonnie Bramlett]] in a revolving troupe of professional musicians and rock superstars dubbed [[Delaney & Bonnie & Friends]]. ==Career== Bramlett was born in [[Pontotoc, Mississippi]], [[United States]]. After a stint in the [[United States Navy]], Bramlett moved to [[Los Angeles, California]], in the early 1960s where he established himself as a [[singer-songwriter]], writing with fellow musicians Joey Cooper, [[Mac Davis]], and [[Jackie DeShannon]]. By 1965, Bramlett was a regular member of the Shindogs, the [[house band]] of the [[television show]], ''[[Shindig!]]''. During this time, he worked with [[J.J. Cale]] and [[Leon Russell]] and released some unsuccessful [[solo (music)|solo]] [[single (music)|singles]].{{Citation needed|date=December 2009}}One of these, "Guess I Must Be Dreamin'" entered the Cashbox "Looking Ahead" survey on 5/14/67. In the late 1960s, [[United Kingdom|British]] guitarist [[Eric Clapton]] joined Delaney & Bonnie & Friends on tour after which Delaney produced and co-wrote songs for Clapton's debut solo album, ''[[Eric Clapton (album)|Eric Clapton]]''. Clapton still credits Delaney for pushing him to sing and teaching him the art of rock vocals.Ward, Ed. [http://www.rollingstone.com/reviews/album/317213/review/6068197 Eric Clapton: ''Eric Clapton'' (review)] at ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', 3 September 1970. Bramlett produced [[King Curtis]]' last LP,[http://indieezine.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=615&Itemid=69 Indie Ezine] which had two hit singles: "Teasin'" and "Lonesome Long Way from Home". Bramlett taught then [[Beatle]] [[George Harrison]] to play [[slide guitar]], which led into a [[gospel music|gospel]] [[jam (music)|jam]] that resulted in Harrison's [[hit record|hit]] "[[My Sweet Lord]]".[http://a1artistspotlight.com/2008/05/22/036-delaney-bramlett-had-george-harrison-eric-clapton-and-some-guy-named-jimi-in-his-band/ A1 Artist Spotlight.com] Bramlett wrote, recorded, or appeared on stage with many notable performers, including [[Joe Cocker]], [[Jimi Hendrix]],[http://www.cduniverse.com/productinfo.asp?pid=6921656 CD Universe Sorry] [[Janis Joplin]], [[Billy Preston]], [[John Lennon]], [[The Everly Brothers]], [[Spooner Oldham]], [[Steve Cropper]] and [[Billy Burnette]]. Members of the ''Friends'' appearing in concert or recording with Bramlett on Friends albums include a galaxy of stars and highly respected side men, including [[Eric Clapton]], [[George Harrison]], [[Leon Russell]], [[King Curtis]], [[Duane Allman]], [[Gregg Allman]], [[Dave Mason]], [[Rita Coolidge]], [[Carl Radle]], [[Jim Gordon (musician)|Jim Gordon]], [[Bobby Whitlock]], [[Jim Keltner]], [[Bobby Keys]], and [[Gram Parsons]]. In 2006, Bramlett was one of the [[duet (music)|duet]] artists on the [[Jerry Lee Lewis]] album ''[[Last Man Standing (Jerry Lee Lewis album)|Last Man Standing]]'',[http://www.pbsfm.org.au/Documents.asp?ID=3992&Title=Jerry+Lee+Lewis+-+Last+Man+Standing%3A+The+Duets PBS 106.7FM - Real Radio - Jerry Lee Lewis - Last Man Standing] singing and playing guitar on "Lost Highway". In 2008, the year of his death, Bramlett released his first CD in six years, ''A New Kind of Blues''.[http://cdbaby.com/cd/delaneybramlett CD Baby: DELANEY BRAMLETT: "A New Kind Of Blues"] The Bramlett's "Never Ending Song of Love" has been covered by others, and appears on the soundtrack of ''[[RV (film)|RV]]'' and ''[[A Good Year]]''.{{IMDb name|0104231}} Bramlett co-wrote the Eric Clapton hit, "Let It Rain".[http://repertoire.bmi.com/title.asp?blnWriter=True&blnPublisher=True&blnArtist=True&keyID=852483&ShowNbr=0&ShowSeqNbr=0&querytype=WorkID Repertoire.bmi.com] On January 18, 2011, Bramlett was inducted into the Mississippi Musicians Hall of Fame.[http://www.theventuremagazine.com/2011/01/delaney-bramletts-in-mississipppi.html Theventuremagazine.com] ==Death== Described in an obituary as a "Southern Legend",[http://www.swampland.com/posts/view/title:delaney_bramlett_the_death_of_a_southern_legend Delaney Bramlett: The Death of a Southern Legend], swampland.com, 27 December 2008. Bramlett died from complications of [[gall bladder]] surgery on December 27, 2008, in [[Los Angeles]], [[California]].[http://www.latimes.com/news/obituaries/la-me-passings28-2008dec28,0,3451708.story Obituary: Delaney Bramlett; songwriter who wrote 'Let It Rain'], ''Los Angeles Times'', December 28, 2008. Delaney was survived by his widow, [[Susan Lanier]]-Bramlett, a brother, John Wayne Bramlett, three daughters, Michele Bramlett, Suzanne Bramlett, [[Bekka Bramlett]], a stepson, Dylan Thomas, and two grandchildren. ==Discography== *1969: ''[[Accept No Substitute]]'' ([[Elektra Records|Elektra]]) *1969: ''[[Home]]'' ([[Stax Records|Stax]]) *1970: ''[[Delaney & Bonnie & Friends on Tour]]'' ([[Warner Bros. Records|WEA]] / [[Atlantic Records|Atlantic]]) *1970: ''[[To Bonnie from Delaney]]'' ([[Atco Records|Atco]]) *1971: ''Motel Shot'' (Atco) *1971: ''Genesis'' (GNP/Crescendo) *1972: ''Somethings Coming'' ([[Columbia Records|Columbia]]) *1972: ''Country Life'' (Atco) *1972: ''D&B Together'' ([[Columbia Records|Columbia]]) *1973: ''Best of Delaney Bramlett'' (Atlantic) *1973: ''Mobius Strip'' (CBS) *1975: ''Giving Birth to a Song'' ([[MGM]]) *1977: ''Class Reunion'' (Prodigal) *1978: ''Delaney Bramlett with Steve Cropper'' ([[Motown Records|Motown]]) *1990: ''Best of Delaney & Bonnie'' ([[Rhino Records|Rhino]]) *1998: ''Sounds From Home'' (DK/Zane) *2002: ''Sweet Inspiration'' (Dreamsville Records) *2008: ''A New Kind of Blues'' (Magnolia Gold)[{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p16058/discography|pure_url=yes}} Allmusic discography] ==Other credits== *1969: [[Elvin Bishop]], ''Best of Elvin Bishop'': "Tulsa Shuffle" - Rhythm guitar, background vocals, producer *1970: [[The Crickets]], ''Rockin' 50's Rock 'n' Roll'' - Producer *1970: Elvin Bishop, ''Best of Elvin Bishop'': "Crabshaw" - Producer *1970: [[Eric Clapton]], ''[[Eric Clapton (album)|Eric Clapton]]'' - Arranger, rhythm guitar, background vocals, producer *1970: [[Leon Russell]], ''Leon Russell'' - Guitar *1970: [[Dave Mason]], ''[[Alone Together (Dave Mason album)|Alone Together]]'' - Guitar, vocals *1971: [[John Simon (record producer)|John Simon]], ''John Simon's Album'' - Tambourine *1972: Elvin Bishop,'' Rock My Soul'' - Guitar, vocals, producer *1972: [[John P. Hammond|John Hammond Jr]], ''I'm Satisfied'' - Producer, vocals, guitar *1972: Eric Clapton, ''[[The History of Eric Clapton]]'' - Guitar, vocals *1972: Eric Clapton, ''[[Eric Clapton at His Best]]'' - Producer *1972: [[Duane Allman]], ''[[An Anthology (Duane Allman album)|An Anthology]]'' - Rhythm guitar, vocals, producer *1972: [[Everly Brothers]], ''Stories We Could Tell'' - Guitar, vocals *1973: [[Jerry Lee Lewis]], ''Sometimes a Memory Ain't Enough'' - Guitar, vocals *1973: [[Pacific Gas & Electric]], ''Best'' - Producer *1973: John Ussery, ''Ussery'' - Percussion, producer, slide guitar *1974: Duane Allman, ''An Anthology Vol. II'' - Guitar, vocals *1976: [[Free Creek (band)|Free Creek]], ''Summit Meeting'' - Guitar *1978: [[Commander Cody and His Lost Planet Airmen|Commander Cody]], ''Flying Dreams'' - Vocals *1978: Dann Rogers, ''Hearts Under Fire'' - Background vocals *1982: Eric Clapton, ''[[Time Pieces: Best of Eric Clapton]]'' - Rhythm guitar, producer *1988: Eric Clapton, ''[[Crossroads (Eric Clapton album)|Crossroads]]'' - Guitar, vocals, producer, horn arrangements *1991: Zoo, ''Shakin' the Cage'' - Background vocals *1992: [[Phil Driscoll]], ''Picture Changes'' - Background vocals *1992: Classic Rock ''Classic Rock'' [Cema] - Producer *1996: ''Heroes of Country Music, Vol. 5'' - Vocals, producer *1997: [[Hank Thompson (musician)|Hank Thompson]], ''Hank, Real Thing'' - Background vocals, [[National String Instrument Corporation|National]] [[dobro]] *1998: [[Ian Whitcomb]], ''You Turn Me On: The Very Best of Ian Whitcomb'' - Bass guitar *1998: [[T. Graham Brown]], ''Wine into Water'' - Guitar, vocals *1999: Dave Mason, ''Ultimate Collection'' - Background vocals *2006: Jerry Lee Lewis, ''[[Last Man Standing (Jerry Lee Lewis album)|Last Man Standing]]'', "Lost Highway" - Vocals[http://www.delaneybramlett.com/ Delaneybramlett.com] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p16058/biography|pure_url=yes}} Delaney Bramlett biography] at [[Allmusic]] * [https://www.myspace.com/delaneybramlett Delaney Bramlett] at [[MySpace]] *{{IMDb name|id=0104231}} {{Authority control|VIAF=71817242}} {{Persondata | NAME = Bramlett, Delaney | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = [[United States|American]] singer, songwriter, musician, and record producer | DATE OF BIRTH = July 1, 1939 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Pontotoc, Mississippi]], United States | DATE OF DEATH = December 27, 2008 | PLACE OF DEATH = [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], United States }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bramlett, Delaney}} [[Category:1939 births]] [[Category:2008 deaths]] [[Category:People from Pontotoc, Mississippi]] [[Category:American male singers]] [[Category:Delaney & Bonnie & Friends members]] [[Category:Songwriters from Mississippi]] [[Category:American record producers]] [[Category:Deaths from surgical complications]] [[Category:Burials at Forest Lawn Memorial Park (Hollywood Hills)]]
